comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: >> Mrs. Julian Linugent This likely is Mrs. Julian L. Nugent

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: On Feb 4, 1915, Mrs Julian L Nugent of St. Louis laid the cornerstone for a YMCA building in Brooklyn, funded by her grandmother Mrs. W. van Rensselaer Smith. See Arizona sentinel and Yuma weekly examiner., February 04, 1915, page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn95060876/1915-02-04/ed-...

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The sun., January 24, 1915, Page 8 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1915-01-24/ed-... indicates that she is a daughter of Clarence E. Smith to whom the building was to be dedicated.

comment.author: 76208917@N06
comment._content: Thank you for helping me find a picture of my grandmother.  She died of cancer at the age of 49, 2 months before I was born. I have very few pictures of her and none of her father Clarence E Smith or his father and mother Roxie Maria and William Van Rensselaer Smith. I believe Clarence died in 1910 at the age of  44.

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: Pixel Wrangler and swanq:  Thanks for clarification on her name, and for the additional background information.  We'll fix the description next time we update.

comment.author: 76208917@N06
comment._content: Mrs Julian Lake Nugent was born Beatrice Provost Smith, I believe in New York. Her mother,  (Florence Josephine Kelley) Mrs. Clarence E. Smith remarried after his death to a Mr. J M. Batterton. Mrs Batterton's  picture is just to the right of her daughter Mrs. Julian  Lake Nugent on your photo stream. William Van Rensselaer Smith was a partner in the Arbuckle Coffee Tea and Sugar Company during the late 1800's until he sold out in 1906. After her husband William's death Roxie Maria Smith gave money to build a YMCA in Brooklyn,NY in memory of her late son Clarence. She also gave money to their church in the name of her husband.

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: @ spider1906 -- it's wonderful that you found this beautiful photograph of your grandmother.  The Smith's and Nugent's certainly have an interesting history!  (I'm going to guess that you are Joan ;)

comment.author: 76208917@N06
comment._content: My name is Jean.  You are probably referring to my cousin Joan, uncle Julians's daughter.

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: @ spider1906, yes I did think you were your uncle Julian's daughter. I confess I did get turned around a couple of times trying to follow all the "Julian's" who were sons of "Julia's" -- and the "Miss Julian's" ! One note I read along the way said that Julian L. Nugent (Senior) was "married twice and had three children." Do you know if that is accurate -- that he was married twice?

comment.author: 76208917@N06
comment._content: My uncle Julian Lake Nugent jr. was married once to Janet Brown. t\They had two daughters  Julie and Joan. My grandfather Julian  Lake Nugent was married three times.Once to Beatrice Provost Smith. They had William Brainard Nugent, my father and Julian Lake Nugent Jr..  My grandfather then married Vera Howard. They had Vera J. Nugent, Audry Nugent and Ann Nices Nugent and Thersa Nugent . Julian later married Ven, nurse for the previous children two of whom died young. Ven and my grandfather then had Julia Nugent. I believe all have died. My great Grandfather Byron was married to Julia  Lake, hence the name Lake.
